newsitem.title: SOUTH AFRICA: PRESS DIGEST - South Africa - June 17.
newsitem.headline: PRESS DIGEST - South Africa - June 17.

text.p: These are the leading stories in the South African press on Tuesday.
Reuters has not verified these stories and does not vouch for their accuracy.

- A showdown is looming between medical aid schemes and about half of the pharmacies in South Africa, which plan to introduce a dispensing fee that could result in patients having to pay cash for prescription medicines.

- A bid to reopen international trade in ivory moved closer when it was announced that all the elephant "range" states in Africa were close to consensus on backing the proposal at the Convention on International Trade in Endangered Species.

- Heavy protection quotas against importing shoes, particularly from China, are to be published soon to give the troubled South African footwear industry a chance to recover from a 50 percent decline in production over the past seven years.

- Oil from gas plant Mossgas has become involved in a spat between the government and South Africa's oil refiners involving more than 50 million rand a year in synthetic fuel levies which the government believes should have been paid for Mossgas products by oil firms.
- An agricultural trade draft policy document proposes that the government negotiate special arrangements for South Africa's emerging farmers with trading partners.
- A proposed merger between mining house JCI and British industrial and mining group Lonrho, has been delayed because of resistance to the deal by Ashanti mining firm, analysts said.
- JCI threatened on Monday to sue the National Union of Mineworkers (NUM) for libel after the union accused JCI chairman Mzi Khumalo of reneging on a deal over worker retrenchments.

- The investment arms of the Congress of South African Trade Unions and the Gauteng region of the South African National Civic Organisation were part of a black empowerment consortium bidding with the Ozz Group for a casino licence in the Randburg Waterfront, the consortium said.
- South Africa needed to work with overseas partners to overcome the legacy of a segregated agriculture system, Thoko Didiza, deputy minister of agriculture, said.

- Durban's Bluff Development Company would go ahead with the development of a 360 million rand tourism complex, pending international investment and an enviromental impact assessment study, the company said.
- Nationale Pers maintained its taxed core earnings, despite tough conditions in the education publishing sector.
- Differences between the government and Cosatu over the government's economic growth strategy have largely been ironed out in monthly meetings between them since February.

- MIH Holdings, the international pay-TV channel has finally shown a profit, though this was mainly a result of changes within the group, including the merger of the European interests of Nethold with Canal Plus.
